abstract.abstracttext:
To compare the intraocular pressure lowering effect of combined
viscocanalostomy
and phacoemulsification and combined
trabeculectomy
and phacoemulsification with mitomycin C in eyes with primary open angle glaucoma.

Forty consecutive
patients
(40 eyes) with primary open angle glaucoma and cataract.
Eyes were assigned randomly either to trabeculectomy with mitomycin C or to viscocanalostomy in combination with phacoemulsification and intraocular lens implantation.

Success rate based on
Intraocular Pressure
.

Mean baseline Intraocular Pressure was 24.0 +/ 2.0 mmHg in the viscocanalostomy group and 23.7 +/ 2.6 mmHg in the trabeculectomy group _PVAL_. Mean postoperative Intraocular Pressure was
13.7 +/ 2.2 mmHg
at _POFT_, _POFT_.8 +/ 3.3 mmHg at _POFT_, and _POFT_.9 +/ 3.0 mmHg at _POFT_ in the viscocanalostomy group and
12.1 +/ 4.0 mmHg
at _POFT_, _POFT_.8 +/ 4.7 mmHg at _POFT_, and _POFT_.1 +/ 4.4 mmHg at _POFT_ in the trabeculectomy group. There was no significant difference in the mean Intraocular Pressure between the groups at any time. At _POFT_, _POFT_ patients _MEAS_ in the viscocanalostomy group and 16 patients _MEAS_ in the trabeculectomy group achieved an Intraocular Pressure of 20 mmHg or less without medication _PVAL_. Complications included 2 cases _MEAS_ of flat/shallow anterior chamber and 4 cases _MEAS_ of hypotony in the trabeculectomy group, whereas intraoperative microperforation of Descemet's membrane occurred in 3 cases _MEAS_ in the viscocanalostomy group.

There was no significant difference in Intraocular Pressure reduction between viscocanalostomy and trabeculectomy with mitomycin C in combination with phacoemulsification and intraocular lens implantation in patients with primary open angle glaucoma.

body.title: Randomized comparison of the intraocular pressure-lowering effect of phacoviscocanalostomy and phacotrabeculectomy.
